EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two 10 to 12 inch diameter trees were knocked and tents were blown over at a campground.  Time of the report was estimated from radar.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms, producing wind damage, tracked north of I-69.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A large tree was blown down, along with several wires.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms, producing wind damage, tracked north of I-69.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A large tree was blown down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms, producing wind damage, tracked north of I-69.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple trees and power lines reported down across the northern part of Bay County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper disturbance moving along and north of a warm front caused severe thunderstorms over portions of the west half of Upper Michigan from the evening of the 2nd into the early morning of the 3rd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers measured 2 to 3 inches of rain across Keweenaw County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper disturbance moving along and north of a warm front caused severe thunderstorms over portions of the west half of Upper Michigan from the evening of the 2nd into the early morning of the 3rd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observer measured 2.35 inches of rain 5 miles west-northwest of Baraga.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper disturbance moving along and north of a warm front caused severe thunderstorms over portions of the west half of Upper Michigan from the evening of the 2nd into the early morning of the 3rd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer in Arnold reported a few trees down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper disturbance moving along and north of a warm front caused severe thunderstorms over portions of the west half of Upper Michigan from the evening of the 2nd into the early morning of the 3rd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers measured 2 to 3 inches of rainfall across Houghton County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front allowed warm and moist air to surge north into Northern Michigan.  Initial thunderstorms developed in Eastern Upper Michigan in the afternoon; some of these produced large hail.  Incoming thunderstorms organized into a line as they crossed Northern Lake Michigan; this squall line produced many reports of 40 to 55mph winds, but only a few pockets of wind damage, in addition to a single tornado.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High water closed US-31 between Garfield and St Marys in the city of Charlevoix.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very warm and unstable airmass produced a few severe thunderstorms over Baraga and Marquette counties on the evening of the 8th.  Some of these storms produced golf ball sized hail in the Marquette area, and a tornado occurred southwest of Big Bay at Eagle Mine.  Storms also produced heavy rain over portions of central Upper Michigan from the evening of the 8th into the morning of the 9th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The High Bridge RAWS station measured 1.88 inches of rainfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A disturbance moving through a warm and unstable air mass produced severe thunderstorms over central Upper Michigan from the evening of the 4th into the morning of the 5th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The storm survey indicated a four-mile path of straight line wind damage across the Sawyer and Edey Lake area east of Channing.  There was evidence of gustnadoes along the main straight line wind core.  Straight-line wind speeds were estimated at 60-70 mph with pockets of near 90 mph winds within the gustnado damage.  Numerous large trees were uprooted with smaller trees snapped off from the strong winds.  Within the area of strongest wind damage several of the large trees fell on houses and vehicles and knocked down power poles and power lines.  The 911 call center also reported that numerous witnesses saw a waterspout on Sawyer Lake which moved onshore towards Woodlawn Lane.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moving through southeast Michigan triggered isolated marginally severe storms. The exception was near Chelsea in Washtenaw county, where thunderstorm wind damage was a bit more focused.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two dozen trees were uprooted or broken in half. A light pole was damaged, along with a silo and shed destroyed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated severe thunderstorms resulted in several reports of damaging wind gusts and large hail.  Several trees were blown down.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A construction barn was destroyed by a lightning strike near Rosebush.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moving through the region generated strong to severe thunderstorms over portions of west and central Upper Michigan on the afternoon of the 20th.

A very warm and unstable airmass produced a few severe thunderstorms over Baraga and Marquette counties on the evening of the 8th.  Some of these storms produced golf ball sized hail in the Marquette area, and a tornado occurred southwest of Big Bay at Eagle Mine.  Storms also produced heavy rain over portions of central Upper Michigan from the evening of the 8th into the morning of the 9th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail was reported at Tourist Park with circular motion noted in the thunderstorm clouds.  Some downed tree branches were also observed at the Jacobetti Tech Center.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A complex of thunderstorms moved east from Wisconsin and Upper Michiga, producing some pockets of wind damage in Northern Lower Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A large number of trees were downed around northern Burt Lake, with the most concentrated damage near Mullet Burt Road and East Burk Lake Road.  Some trees were were downed onto homes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe storms impacted the Detroit Metro Area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees reported down across 12 Mile Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Passage of a strong cold front generated widespread showers and thunderstorms which dumped heavy rain across much of the west half of Upper Michigan on the 25th.  A few of the storms in Marquette and Menominee counties turned severe producing large hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Penny-sized hail was reported in Negaunee.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front was located across portions of northern Indiana. Elevated instability and steep lapse rates allowed for the development of several thunderstorms. Several hail reports were received, mainly less than three quarters of an inch in diameter. One isolated report of one inch diameter hail was received with a stronger thunderstorm.

A cold front moved through southern lower Michigan during the afternoon hours. Surface temperatures in the upper 80s to around 90 and dewpoints in the 60s allowed for most unstable CAPE values approaching 1000 j/kg. Shear was less than 30 knots, limiting overall growth potential of the storms, but still allowing for isolated storms to produce damaging winds and large hail in a few locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management officials reported trees and power lines down on Wheeler Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms developed during the late afternoon hours, impacting areas mostly along the M-59 corridor.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and power lines reported blown down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Passage of a strong cold front generated widespread showers and thunderstorms which dumped heavy rain across much of the west half of Upper Michigan on the 25th.  A few of the storms in Marquette and Menominee counties turned severe producing large hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An auto dealership just northeast of Negaunee reported significant damage to four cars from hail.  Hail size was estimated using other reports from the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An amplified, upper level weather pattern allowed for an unseasonably warm and humid air mass to infiltrate the southern Great Lakes region.  Highly anomalous for the month of March, surface dew points climbed into the lower 60 degree range across much of Southeastern Michigan. This rich moisture combined with an upper level disturbance tracking northward through Lower Michigan to fuel a long duration severe thunderstorm event across Southeastern Michigan. The primary severe weather type observed with these storms was very large hail, along with 3 tornadoes.
An upper disturbance moving through the area produced severe thunderstorms over portions of central Upper Michigan on the afternoon of the 9th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dozens of tree branches were snapped off, and several large trees more than 18 inches in diameter fell onto grave markers at the Riverside Cemetery.  Extensive tree damage was also reported at the Riverside Golf Club.  Many trees greater than two feet in diameter were uprooted across the course.  Very strong winds were observed by the golf club staff, but no damage was apparent to buildings.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moving through the region generated strong to severe thunderstorms over portions of west and central Upper Michigan on the afternoon of the 20th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail lasted five minutes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moving through a warm and unstable airmass produced isolated severe thunderstorms over south central Upper Michigan on the afternoon of the 28th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Power lines and trees were reported down across the railroad tracks in Menominee.  Emergency services were activated for the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated severe thunderstorms resulted in several reports of damaging wind gusts and large hail.  Several trees were blown down.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported seven eighths inch diameter hail.
